description: From Middle English example, from Old French essample, from Latin exemplum (“sample, pattern, specimen, copy for imitation, etc.”, literally “what is taken out”); see exempt. Doublet of exemplum and sample. Displaced native Old English bȳsn.

entries.meaning: Something that is representative of all such things in a group.
Something that serves to illustrate or explain a rule.
Something that serves as a pattern of behaviour to be imitated (a good example) or not to be imitated (a bad example).
examples: Nelson Mandela was an example for many to follow.

entries.meaning: A person punished as a warning to others.
A parallel or closely similar case, especially when serving as a precedent or model.
An instance (as a problem to be solved) serving to illustrate the rule or precept or to act as an exercise in the application of the rule.

verbs.description: example (third-person singular simple present examples, present participle exampling, simple past and past participle exampled)
